Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: almost; approximately; near; on the verge of
Hedge Example: There are about 10 million packages in transit right now.
Non-hedge Definition: regarding; near (as in 'he has a funny air about him'); other
Non-hedge Example: We need to talk about Mark.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: The robbers took almost everything.
Non-hedge Example: Other

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: according to appearances or incomplete evidence
Hedge Example: Apparently John had a doctor's appointment and that's why he couldn't make it.
Non-hedge Example: Other

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to give the impression of being
Hedge Example: The problem appears to be a bug in the software.
Non-hedge Definition: to come into sight; to be part of a stage performance
Non-hedge Example: A bird I didn't recognize appeared in our yard on Sunday.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: He will be there in approximately ten minutes.
Non-hedge Example: The tofu was meant to approximate turkey.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: Whether or not this is the best idea is arguable.
Non-hedge Definition: susceptible to being supported by a convincing argument
Non-hedge Example: He is arguably the best player in the history of the team.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: I assumed this position was temporary.
Non-hedge Definition: to take on; to take over; to take upon oneself
Non-hedge Example: I assumed this position upon his retirement.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: I have a basic understanding of this concept.
Non-hedge Example: Students learn the basics of business in this class.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: So basically you add up your R squareds and whatever's left is unexplained variability.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to think; to hold as an opinion; to believe something
Hedge Example: I believe I met him at last year's picnic.
Non-hedge Definition: to believe in; to believe someone
Non-hedge Example: I believe you.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: You could be right.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to form a theory; a conjecture

Definition of Hedge Type: imply that the speaker attributes information to some other source in order to downplay it OR to garner power for their statement rather than committing to the proposition themselves
Hedge Definition: to reference information acquired by overhearing it somewhere
Hedge Example: I heard that they're building a new school two blocks down.
Non-hedge Example: I hear the birds sing under my window every morning.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: to great extent; in great part
Hedge Example: It is largely known that this university has a good reputation and an excellent track record.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: similar to; approximately; when used as a discourse filler word; et cetera (e.g. 'and the like')
Hedge Example: So in this case time off is like a mandatory benefit.
Non-hedge Definition: to feel attraction toward; to enjoy; to want; to approve of; such as; as if
Non-hedge Example: They like bathtime as much as they like doing homework - not at all.

Hedge Example: Maybe he will actually win this year.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if the speaker is uncertain or appears to be deliberately underspecifying
Hedge Example: There are some contexts in which this behavior would be inapproriate.

Non-hedge Example: Some days it's so hard to get up.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)

Non-hedge Definition: when used as a grammatical necessity or when specification would not be necessary in the context of the conversation
Non-hedge Example: It would be so easy for somebody to disturb something here.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if the speaker is uncertain or appears to be deliberately underspecifying; in some manner
Hedge Example: And then the reagents react somehow and we get a new chemical byproduct.
Non-hedge Definition: when used as a grammatical necessity or when specification would not be necessary in the context of the conversation
Non-hedge Example: We're just going to have to scrounge up the money somehow.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if the speaker is uncertain or appears to be deliberately underspecifying
Hedge Example: Someone will have to clean up this mess.
Non-hedge Definition: when used as a grammatical necessity or when specification would not be necessary in the context of the conversation; or to indicate a specific person
Non-hedge Example: I am someone to trust.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if the speaker is uncertain or appears to be deliberately underspecifying; infrequently
Hedge Example: The health inspectors comes around unexpectedly sometimes.
Non-hedge Definition: when used as a grammatical necessity or when specification would not be necessary in the context of the conversation
Non-hedge Example: Sometimes you win and sometimes you lose but what's important is your attitude.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if the speaker is uncertain or appears to be deliberately underspecifying
Hedge Example: I noticed that the car was somewhat scratched up after your little joy ride.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if the speaker is uncertain or appears to be deliberately underspecifying
Hedge Example: It's somewhere close to nine o'clock right now.
Non-hedge Definition: when used as a grammatical necessity or when specification would not be necessary in the context of the conversation
Non-hedge Example: I'm sure you'll find your keys somewhere.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to form a theory or conjecture
Hedge Example: I can only speculate as to why they showed up today.
Non-hedge Definition: to engage in a business transaction
Non-hedge Example: He was a trader who speculated on the price of oil.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to cause one to think that something is the case; to put forward for consideration
Hedge Example: The results suggest that the procedure is effective.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to assume; to take without evidence
Hedge Example: I suppose the package will arrive next week.
Non-hedge Example: I'm supposed to call if I'm going to be late.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: He surely must have knowledge of this.
Non-hedge Definition: in a sure and confident manner
Non-hedge Example: He stepped surely across the chasm.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: Technically this isn't completely correct.
Non-hedge Definition: having to do with a display of skill; technologically advanced
Non-hedge Example: The performance of that concerto was technically sound and emotionally expressive.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: I think it's an important issue.
Non-hedge Example: I thought of the solution.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: to perceive; to hold a point of view
Hedge Example: I understand it to the in the range of $30-40 million.
Non-hedge Example: I understand what you are saying.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: The candidate is unlikely to win the race.
Non-hedge Example: He is an unlikely mate.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: I'm unsure about this.
Non-hedge Example: The footing on the bridge was unsure.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: Mr. Smith usually comes by the coffeeshop half past eight.
Non-hedge Example: Other

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: The signal is virtually untraceable.
Non-hedge Example: He virtually changed her password and reset the connection.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: if negated - to indicate uncertainty about the conveyed information
Hedge Example: I can't recall the exact numbers but they were miniscule.
Non-hedge Definition: if negated - to indicate actual inability to remember information; if not negated - all meanings
Non-hedge Example: I don't recall where I put my keys.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: if negated - to indicate uncertainty about the conveyed information
Hedge Example: I can't remember the exact numbers but they were miniscule.
Non-hedge Definition: if negated - to indicate actual inability to remember information; if not negated - all meanings
Non-hedge Example: I can't remember where I put my keys.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Example: I don't know if that's a good idea.
Non-hedge Definition: if negated - meaning 'to not possess information'; if not negated - all meanings
Non-hedge Example: I don't know her phone number.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: She is not totally convinced of the team's strategy.
Non-hedge Example: She is totally wasted.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Definition: if negated - meaning 'not to a total extent'
Hedge Example: She is not completely convinced of the team's strategy.
Non-hedge Example: He is completely wasted.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: There isn't much going on in that part of town.
Non-hedge Example: John is driving much faster than the speed limit.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: if negated - meaning 'as a logical result'
Hedge Example: That is not necessarily the case.
Non-hedge Example: Taking care of puppies necessarily involves a lot of cleaning.

Definition of Hedge Type: introduce uncertainty or ambiguity into the content of the utterance itself (i.e. the speaker/author is fully committed to what they are saying but there is something imprecise in the content itself)
Hedge Example: He is not really one for talking.
Non-hedge Example: The soup is really hot.

Definition of Hedge Type: create uncertainty in the commitment of the speaker to what they are saying (eg. 'I [think] (some fact)' as opposed to 'I [know] (some fact)')
Hedge Definition: if negated - to express a presence or lack of confidence with respect to something
Hedge Example: I'm not sure what the exact numbers are.
Non-hedge Example: The footing was even and sure.
